Starmer and Sturgeon blow hole in bid to ease lockdown: Labour and Scottish leaders say it's too early to lift restrictions as poll shows 2/3rds are worried about it ending too early as Boris prepares to unveil road map back to normality

Boris Johnson is expected to set out the next phase of the response to the crisis in an address to the nation on Sunday night. He said yesterday that 'easements' will be outlined to the restrictions. Downing Street played down the extent of the changes this afternoon, saying Mr Johnson told the Cabinet there would be 'maximum caution'. But ministers have made clear the 'stay at home' mantra will be replaced with a more nuanced approach, while more people will be urged to return to work where possible. Nicola Sturgeon took an axe to the UK's united front on coronavirus as she said downgrading the advice now would be potentially catastrophic. Saying she will not be pressurised by Westminster, she insisted there can be no loosening at all for at least another week - and suggested rules will be largely unchanged in Scotland for the rest of the month. Meanwhile, Labour's Keir Starmer has suggested lockdown must stay in place until testing capacity is much higher - after daily numbers slumped below 100,000 again. He said a track and trace regime was critical for controlling the outbreak, and 'if that's going to happen the planning needs to go in now because we need many many more tests than we've got already'. A poll for MailOnline has also highlighted the challenge 'coronaphobia' among the public will pose to the government getting the country running again.

Last chance for some lockdown sun? 79F heatwave makes UK hotter than Corfu tomorrow before Arctic air brings wintry showers on Sunday and Britain readies for return to work

Tomorrow will see the mercury hitting up to 79F (26C) in London, with conditions staying warm on Saturday (top right, inset, map showing warm air rising from the south). The end of the weekend will see a stark contrast, as Arctic air brings wintry showers to the nation on Sunday, according to the Met Office. Parts of the country are forecast to be hotter than some of the Europe's top tourist destinations, including Monaco and Corfu. Meanwhile, today could see temperatures hitting up to 73F (23C) in warmer spots with potentially thundery showers developing in Wales (top, a woman takes a selfie on Primrose Hill in London and bottom left, people walk along the beach in Poole, Dorset). But many beaches and open spaces are likely to be largely empty as people stay at home due to the coronavirus lockdown. It comes ahead of Prime Minister Boris Johnson announcing a five-step plan for Britain's 'second phase' of the pandemic on Sunday, with the government set to drop its 'Stay at Home' message (bottom right, a police officer approaches a member of the public sunbathing on Primrose Hill).

Was it all a waste of time? Study finds stay-at-home orders had little effect on curbing coronavirus

Researchers at the University of East Anglia studied lockdown measures in 30 countries around the world and found that some measures were more effective than others at reducing the spread of COVID-19. One of the scientists, Dr Julii Brainard, said telling everyone to stay at home and closing all non-essential businesses added 'very little additional effect' to attempts to stop the virus. Their paper comes as Prime Minister Boris Johnson is this weekend expected to announce changes to Britain's current rules which could include relaxing limits on how much time people can spend outside. Pictured: School closures (top left) and mass gathering bans (bottom left) were effective, the researchers found, but forcing everyone to stay at home (top right) and closing all businesses (bottom right) may have been unnecessary.

Shocking moment eight 'brain dead' bikers ride the WRONG way down a dual carriageway causing father-of-three to swerve out the way to avoid a horrific collision

Joe Broadway had just been to drop some food off at his child's house in Tilbury, Essex, on Sunday and was travelling down the A1089 near Grays, Essex. Less than half a mile from an exit for the busy A13, the 35-year-old spotted an oncoming group of vehicles in the distance, but assumed they were on the correct side of the road. It wasn't until he passed a long bend that Mr Broadway was faced with a bike driving down the thin hard shoulder towards him, forcing him to veer into the outside lane.

Not so green energy: Hundreds of non-recyclable fiberglass wind turbine blades are pictured piling up in landfill

The municipal landfill in Casper, Wyoming, is the repository of at least 870 discarded blades, and one of the few locations in the country that accepts the massive fiberglass objects. Built to withstand hurricane winds, the turbine blades cannot easily be crushed or recycled. About 8,000 of the blades are decommissioned in the U.S. every year. Once they reach the end of their useful life on electricity-generating wind turbines, the blades have to be hacked up with industrial saws into pieces small enough to fit on a flat-bed trailer and hauled to a landfill that accepts them.
